title: My New Side Hustle: Aesthetic Producer for AI Agents
excerpt: A friend's AI startup has created an unexpected opportunity for me to apply my aesthetic sensibilities to the emerging world of AI social media agents.
content:
When my university friend PJ called last month asking for my input on his startup's latest project, I had no idea it would turn into a fascinating side hustle. PJ founded TheDriftAgentic, a cutting-edge company specializing in AI commercial and video applications. His newest venture? Creating sophisticated AI agents that help brands and individuals manage their social media presence and online shopping experiences.

What started as casual advice about the visual aspects of these AI personas has evolved into a part-time role that he's calling "Aesthetic Producer" — and it's opening my eyes to yet another dimension of how AI is transforming creative industries.

Understanding AI Agents

For those unfamiliar with the concept (as I was initially), AI agents are essentially customized artificial intelligence assistants designed for specific purposes. Unlike general AI like ChatGPT, these agents have defined personalities, specialized knowledge bases, and specific functions — whether that's helping consumers find fashion items that match their style preferences, creating personalized travel itineraries, or curating home décor recommendations.

What makes TheDriftAgentic's approach unique is their focus on creating agents with cohesive, authentic personalities rather than generic assistants. These agents have consistent visual styles, communication patterns, and even simulated backgrounds and interests that make interacting with them feel more like connecting with a knowledgeable friend than using a search engine.

My Role as Aesthetic Producer

When PJ first showed me some of their agent prototypes, I immediately noticed that while the technical functionality was impressive, the visual and tonal elements felt disconnected. An agent specializing in sustainable fashion recommendations had a visual style that felt more corporate than eco-conscious. Another focused on luxury travel used imagery that was technically high-end but lacked the subtle sophistication that genuinely affluent travelers would respond to.

Drawing on my experience creating cohesive hospitality and event experiences, I suggested ways to align each agent's visual identity, tone of voice, and content curation to create more convincing and compelling personas. PJ was so impressed with my feedback that he asked if I'd consider joining as a consultant to help define the aesthetic dimension of their agent development process.

Now, a few weeks in, I'm working about 10 hours a week remotely with their team. My responsibilities include:

  • Creating mood boards and visual direction guides for new agent personas
  • Reviewing and refining the image selection parameters that determine what visual content the agents share
  • Helping define the "visual vocabulary" that shapes how agents present information visually
  • Ensuring cultural authenticity and sensitivity in how agents represent different aesthetic traditions

The E-Commerce Connection

One particularly interesting aspect of this work involves agents designed to enhance online shopping experiences. These specialized AI assistants help consumers find products that truly match their aesthetic preferences and practical needs — a significant improvement over traditional recommendation algorithms that rely heavily on purchase history and simplistic category matching.

For example, I've been working on an agent focused on home décor that can recognize a client's existing aesthetic from photos of their space, then suggest new pieces that would complement their style. Another fashion-focused agent helps users build capsule wardrobes by understanding their lifestyle, body type, color preferences, and even how they want to feel in their clothes.

What makes these agents powerful is their ability to understand nuanced aesthetic concepts rather than just keywords. They can distinguish between different interpretations of "minimalist" or "bohemian" and make recommendations that match the specific version a user prefers.

The Challenges

This work isn't without challenges. There's still a significant gap between how these agents present themselves and what they can actually deliver. The technology sometimes struggles with the subjective nature of aesthetic judgment, and there's always the risk of reinforcing narrow beauty standards or cultural stereotypes if the training data isn't sufficiently diverse.

I've been particularly vocal about ensuring these agents respect and accurately represent diverse aesthetic traditions. When we were developing an agent specializing in global interior design styles, I pushed for consultation with cultural experts to ensure we weren't reducing rich design traditions to superficial visual clichés.

There's also the underlying concern about transparency. Users should always know they're interacting with an AI rather than a human, even when that AI has a well-developed persona. TheDriftAgentic is committed to clear disclosure, but as these technologies become more sophisticated, the line between automated and human interaction grows increasingly blurry.

A Perfect Complement

What I'm enjoying most about this side project is how it complements my main work in Martinborough. The skills I've developed creating cohesive, emotionally resonant experiences for hospitality and events translate surprisingly well to designing the aesthetic dimensions of AI personas.

It's also keeping me connected to cutting-edge technology while living in a rural wine region. There's something delightfully incongruous about helping shape the future of digital interaction while looking out at centuries-old winemaking traditions.

The extra income is certainly welcome as I continue establishing my business in a new location, but the intellectual stimulation is equally valuable. Working with engineers, data scientists, and UX designers exposes me to different ways of thinking and problem-solving that ultimately inform my main work in unexpected ways.

Looking Ahead

I'm not sure how long this side hustle will continue or where it might lead. The field is evolving so rapidly that roles like "AI Aesthetic Producer" might not even exist in their current form a year from now. But I'm enjoying the journey and the opportunity to apply my aesthetic sensibilities in this emerging domain.

What fascinates me most is how these technologies are blurring the lines between traditionally separate industries and disciplines. My background in hospitality, events, and fashion is proving relevant to digital product development in ways I never would have anticipated.

For anyone in creative fields watching the rise of AI with concern, my experience suggests that human aesthetic judgment, cultural understanding, and emotional intelligence remain essential even as technical capabilities advance. These technologies aren't replacing human creativity but opening new channels for its application.

And if nothing else, helping shape how AI represents and interprets aesthetic concepts has made me more conscious of my own design decisions and more articulate about the visual languages I use in my primary work. That alone makes this unexpected detour worthwhile.
